summary.seg: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.31 (hereafter MS R.14.31) is a medical manuscript that was made in Canterbury in the 12th century at either Christ Church Cathedral Priory or St Augustine's Abbey; either way, the volume was a part of the St Augustine's library until the dispersal of its manuscripts in the 16th century. Its contents are entirely medical: the manuscript begins with a text on surgery before progressing through a series of medical receptaria organised around the treatment of specific conditions, and closes with treatises on the medicinal properties of wines and of various plants.

Among the medical texts in this manuscript, one of the most interesting is that which incorporates passages from the De materia medica of Dioscorides Dioscorides Pedanius, of Anazarbos (ff. 165r-226v). De materia medica was translated from the original Greek into Latin in Late Antiquity and was popular in north western Europe throughout the middle ages. De materia medica was translated into Latin more than once, and also into vernacular languages in the later medieval period. The popularity of the Latin versions of De materia medica as well as its length meant that it was often copied in abbreviated forms, disseminated with other similar material, and presented with explanatory prefaces and associated texts. As a consequence, the text can appear rather differently in manuscript sources, and it is not always easy to discern what is a copy of De materia medica with some interpolations, and what should be considered to be a new text based on De materia medica.

The text on ff. 165r-226v in MS R.14.31 incorporates substantial portions of De materia medica. Of the many surviving Latin recensions of this text, that in MS R.14.31 seems most closely to resemble the version in Munich, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, Clm 337 , which was edited by Hermann Stadler across several articles around the turn of the 20th century. However, further work is needed to establish the sources of the text(s) in MS R.14.31: the segments of De materia medica do not appear in the same order that they appear in typical copies of the Latin De materia medica, and the text is frequently interpolated with other unidentified medical content. For example, the chapter 'De edera' at the opening of Book 1 in MS R.14.31, beginning 'Cissos id est edere multe sunt species' (MS R.14.31, f. 165v; Munich, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, Clm 337, f. 69va (ch. PΞE) ; and Hermann's edition, p. 244 seq.) diverges from that found in BSB Clm 337 in later chapters (this is just one of several points of similarity then difference between the two manuscripts).

Medical books were not typically among the most lavishly decorated products of an English monastic scriptorium, nevertheless MS R.14.31 has delicate touches of decoration throughout, including rubricated capitulae, 'arabesque' initials at the beginning of most major and minor divisions of the text in red, green, or blue, and alternately coloured initials for each lemma in the capitula lists, e.g., f. 157r. There is one significant decorative initial in the volume, a 'Q' on f. 1r that terminates in the lower margin with a beautiful frond-like flourish emerging from the mouth of a humanoid figure wearing a little 'Phrygian' cap. These caps were sometimes used as a visual shorthand for 'doctor' in medieval art, later superseded by a figure posing with a urine flask.

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer for the Curious Cures Project
Cambridge University Library

foliation.note: 'Core' medieval leaves foliated as ff. 1-244 in ink in the late-medieval/early modern forms of Hindu-Arabic numerals in the centre of the upper margin of each recto and additional foliation in pencil in Roman numerals to four parchment endleaves (ff. i-iv) at the beginning of the volume. In order to produce a functional TEI/XML record for this item, unfoliated endleaves at the beginning and end of the volume were assigned virtual folio designations in autumn 2023 - these virtual designations are enclosed in [square brackets] in this record.

collation.p:
Quires and endleaves arranged as follows:
Former binding fragment, now free stub (f. [a]) |
Two paper endleaves (ff. [b]-[c]) |
Four parchment endleaves (ff. i-iv) +
Quires 1-298 (ff. 1-232)
Quire 3014-2 (ff. 233-244; 3rd and 4th leaves cancelled, stubs visible) |
Four parchment endleaves (ff. 245-248) |
Two paper endleaves (ff. [d]-[e]) |
Former binding fragment, now free stub (f. [f]) |

p.formula: f. [a] | ff. [b]-[c] | ff. i-iv + Quires 1-298 3014-2 (3rd and 4th cancelled) | ff. 245-248 | ff. [d]-[e] | f. [f]

signatures.p: No leaf signatures common to the entire volume.
Quires 1-30 are numbered in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords common to the entire volume.

binding.p: Armorial binding of George Willmer (1582-1626) George Willmer, 1582-1626 of Stratford-le-Bow, Middlesex. Rebacked.

Full bound in leather over pasteboards with matching decoration in blind to front and rear covers. Covers are each decorated with a quintuple-fillet in blind set at the perimeter of the boards and a gilt single fillet superimposed over the central fillet in the blind quintuple-fillet roll. Blind single fillet on the cover material over the head, fore, and tail edges of the boards. A large gilt armorial stamp in the centre of the cover blazoned as follows:
Crest: mural coronet, eagle displayed
Helmet: esquire
Mantle: acanthus, terminal tassles
Escutcheon: a chevron between three eagles displayed
Motto: 'expertus credo'

Rebacked in leather with a defined grain. Four raised bands on spine. Spine is decorated with a blind single fillet along the upper and lower perimeter of each compartment and at the head and tail openings of the back. Spine is capped at head and tail, no head or tail bands visible. Three small printed paper labels fixed to spine with an adhesive 'R', '1' and '3', the middle label probably originally '10' for a former shelfmark 'R.10.3'.

No pastedowns. A former shelfmark 'R.10.3' written in ink on the inside of the front cover and struck out. Two paper endleaves at either end of the volume, ff. [b]-[c] and [d]-[e], the outermost of these (ff. [b] and [e]) probably once pastedowns in the volume as both have traces of adhesive stains on their outermost faces.

Two parchment stubs (ff. [a] and [f]), one at either end of the volume between the inner face of the cover and the outermost paper endleaves. These stubs were probably once fixed to the inner covers to reinforce the hinges but both are now free and are described separately as they contain medieval text.

Two paper endleaves at each end of the volume, ff. [b]-[c] and [d]-[e]; all of the paper endleaves are blank. A small portion of a watermark is visible on f. [b] at the gutter, but not enough of the mark is visible to identify the design.

accMat.p: A paper slip c. 205 x 80 mm printed with handling guidance for readers is typically stored between ff. [b] and [c]. The slip also contains notes in pencil advising readers of the structure of the volume and directing readers to use the pencil or ink foliation sequences as appropriate.

provenance.p: Probably made at and certainly owned by the community of St Augustine's Abbey, CanterburySt. Augustine's Abbey (Canterbury, England). A St Augustine's shelfmark is present on f. ii recto: 'Di XII. Gradus. III' as well as an ownership inscription, 'lib sci aug cant' (i.e., Liber Sancti Augustini Cantuarii).

listBibl.bibl: M. R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge: A Descriptive Catalogue, 4 vols (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1901), II

provenance.p: Owned by John Twyne (?1505-1581) Twyne, John, approximately 1501-1581 , Canterbury schoolmaster and collector of manuscripts. Twyne added his name in ink on f. ii recto: 'Liber Joannis Twini Senioris'.

listBibl.bibl: A. G. Watson, 'John Twyne of Canterbury (d. 1581) as a Collector of Medieval Manuscripts: A Preliminary Investigation' The Library, 6th ser., 8 (1986), pp. 133–151, esp. p. 148, [doi.org/10.1093/library/s6-VIII.2.133]

provenance.p: Owned by George Willmer (1582-1626) George Willmer, 1582-1626 of Stratford-le-Bow, Middlesex.

acquisition.p: Given to Trinity College by George Willmer (1582-1626) George Willmer, 1582-1626 (1582-1626). Willmer donated 38 manuscripts to Trinity College and the donation is recorded in the College Donors Book on p. 96.

recordHist.source: This catalogue record draws on M. R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge: A Descriptive Catalogue, 4 vols (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1901), II, no. 904.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.31, f. [a]

msItem.title: List of names
msItem.note: List of latinised English names in a 15th century hand.

support.material: Parchment; former binding fragment pasted across the left hinge and probably once covered with a pastedown.

collation.p: Former binding fragment, now free stub (f. [a]) |

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: In good condition; as this leaf was used to strengthen the binding rather than as a text-leaf within the context of this volume, some of the text on f. [a] verso disappears into the gutter.

p.seg: Informally written list of names; original mise-en-page no longer possible to determine due to the trimming of the leaf to re-use as a binding support.

handNote.p: Written in an informal script with a mixture of anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: No significant decoration in this Part.

note.p: The shelfmark 'R.14.31' in ink on f. [a] recto.

binding.p: It seems very probable that this fragment (f. [a]) was once used as a binding support and was pasted from inside the back and over the hinge onto the inside of the left board before being covered with a pastedown as there are patterns of adhesive residue indicative of such use. Folio [a] (and the similar f. [f] at the end of the volume) were not noticed or described by M.R. James in his Catalogue of the Trinity College manuscripts printed between 1900-1904, so it seems likely that the pastedowns were lifted and the stubs were freed after 1904.

note.p: Date and place of production assigned based on palaeographical features and the forms of the names on this fragment.

msItem.title: De uirtutibus medicine - main text
msItem.author: Copho
msItem.rubric: 19v Incipit liber de uirtutibus mediicne secundum medicum choph
msItem.incipit: 19v De perfecte temperatis . Perfecte temperata dicuntur que nullius qualitatis attrahunt excessum . et in quibus caliditatis
msItem.explicit: 37v aliis libris non modicam parare utilitatem

msItem.note: This text also appears in Cambridge, Gonville and Caius MS 379/599, ff. 1r-5r , where it is attributed to Johannes de Sancto Paulo Johannes de Sancto Paulo .

msItem.title: De modo medendi
De modo medendi - chapter list
msItem.incipit: 37v De modo medendi . Quot et quibus modis medetur . De primo modo et secundum locum in quo continentur materia
msItem.explicit: 38v De electuariis quibus proprie dari debeant et de laxatiuis
msItem.note: No numbers in chapter list; capitula laid out like a prose text.

msItem.title: De modo medendi - main text
msItem.incipit: 38v In medendis corporibus et maxime purgandis uariis sepe molestamur incomodis
msItem.explicit: 66v Yeralogodion proprie datur flegmaticis . scabiosis . elefantiosis . cum scamonea . epilenticis cum cocleario salis . et de his HACTENUS

msItem.note: This text is often attributed to Copho Copho .

msItem.title: Unidentified medical text
msItem.incipit: 66v Apostolicon sic fit . Litargiri uncias .uii. Cere rubee . Colofonie amborum
msItem.explicit: 93r in acutis febribus si inungantur timpora Nares . uole manuum et pedum

msItem.title: Tractatus de confectione syruporum
msItem.incipit: 93r Tractatum quem uobis rogantibus promisi de syrupis . et aquis . et oleis
msItem.explicit: 104v si semina calidarum herbarum apponatur

msItem.title: Extracts from De materia medica [Latin] (Book 5)
msItem.author: Dioscorides
msItem.incipit: 104v Vina gipsata accepta ; neruis contraria sunt
msItem.explicit: 109r et stomachi compescit . Menstruis imperat . secundas excludit
msItem.note: This text seems to be a redaction of some of the wine chapters in Book 5 of the Latin translation of Dioscorides' De materia medica (see Stadler (1902), esp. p. 172, ln. 4 seq.). Note that the text in Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.31 begins with text from the end of a chapter in that edition headed 'De uina uetera', introduced in MS R.14.31 as 'Uina gipsata' and ends in MS R.14.31 with a chapter on 'Uina diptamiten'. A variant of the text exists in Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS Lat. 9332, ff. 306v-321v where it corresponds with some of the chapters between ch 9 (f. 307va) - ch 68 (f. 312r).

msItem.note: Although the prologue refers to this text as a work of Constantinus Africanus Constantinus Africanus, d. before 1098/1099 , this is one of the many works of Arabic medicine that Constantinus Africanus translated from Arabic into Latin in the 11th century.

msItem.title: Unidentified medical text incorporating parts of Dioscorides' De materia medica
msItem.textLang: Latin with occasional plant names glossed in Middle English
msItem.note: Title added in the outer margin of f. 165r in ink in an early modern hand 'Tractatus Medicina in quatuor Libri Distinctus'.

Various capitulae in this item are taken from the Latin translation of the De materia medica of Dioscorides Dioscorides Pedanius, of Anazarbos . De materia medica was translated from the original Greek into Latin in Late Antiquity and was popular in north western Europe throughout the middle ages, where it was translated into Latin more than once, and also into vernacular languages in the later medieval period. The Latin version of the De materia medica that seems most closely related to parts of the text in MS R.14.31 was edited primarily from Munich, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, Clm 337 by Hermann Stadler across several articles around the turn of the 20th century. The segments of De materia medica that appear in MS R.14.31 do not appear in the same order that they appear in most typical copies of the Latin text, and it is frequently interpolated with content from elsewhere. Readers may wish to compare the chapter at the opening of 'Book 1' in this item at f. 165v headed 'De edera' and beginning 'Cissos id est edere multe sunt species' with Hermann's edition (p. 244 seq.) and München, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, Clm 337, f. 69va (ch. PΞE) and then note the subsequent divergence of Trinity MS R.14.31 from the text in BSB Clm 337 in later chapters; this is just one of several points of similarity and then difference between the two manuscripts.

msItem.title: Medical recipe in Latin: 'Ad usturam'
msItem.note: Full transcription: 'Ad ustusturam Cerfolium et teneritas rubi . Seuum ueruecinum bene terantur et ad ignem liquatur et firmus anserinus additur . et per pannum colatur'
Also transcribed and briefly discussed in Hunt, 'Anglo-Norman Medical Receipts'.

listBibl.bibl: T. Hunt, 'Anglo-Norman Medical Receipts', in Anglo-Norman Anniversary Essays, ed. by I. Short, Anglo-Norman Text Society: Occasional Publication Series, 2 (London, 1993), pp. 179-235, esp. pp. 181-182

msItem.title: Medical recipe in Old French: 'Ad cancrum
msItem.textLang: Old French with headword in Latin and a plant name translated into Middle English
msItem.note: Full transcription: 'Ad cancrum . Pernez la caneilide ce est en engleis henne uuol . sin fates sekier . sin faites puldre . Si pernez del tan sin faites puldre . Si pernez de feues neires . sis faites sekier sin faites puldre . Or prendrez cez quatre pluldres . de cascun par peis. si pernez lalbun des oes si tribles ensemble que seit espes cum emplastre . Si pernez les escales des oes sis emplez de ce . si pernez les escales puis . si metez en lastre del fu . la buce des escales sur lastre e des carbuns tun entur . e issi que lastre seit bient cald . si laisez iloc tant estre que les escales seint bien neires . pernez de ceste puldre si salesu uus uerez que le cancre iert . si laisez de lied . el tierz iur sil resalez . el siste iur sil resalez uncore de cestre puldre sis laisez issi . '
Also transcribed and briefly discussed in Hunt, 'Anglo-Norman Medical Receipts'.
According to T. Hunt, this is the earliest surviving vernacular medical recipe in Anglo-Norman French.

listBibl.bibl: Dean and Boulton, Anglo-Norman Literature: A Guide to Texts and Manuscripts (1999), no. 439

T. Hunt, 'Anglo-Norman Medical Receipts', in Anglo-Norman Anniversary Essays, ed. by I. Short, Anglo-Norman Text Society: Occasional Publication Series, 2 (London, 1993), pp. 179-235, esp. pp. 181-182

p.secFol: Sec. fol. main text: 2r: combustum et folium

list.item: Quire 3014-2 (ff. 233-244; 3rd and 4th leaves cancelled, stubs visible)

catchwords.seg: Catchwords mostly trimmed away, traces visible in the lower margin of the last verso of some quires, e.g., f. 208v

supportDesc.condition: In good condition. The binding is a little tight and so some text near the inner margins is difficult to read.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Ruled in single column format, 22 lines to the page and written above top line. Capitula lists are ruled and written in double-column format.

handNote.p: Folios 1r-244r are written in protogothic minuscule in a style typical of scribal work produced in England and Norther France during the 12th century. The 'main texts' appear to be the work of a single scribe, but there are glosses and annotations throughout in at least 2 roughly contemporary hands.

decoNote.p: Flourished initials in the 'Arabesque' style at the major divivisons of the texts. A particularly siginficant initial on f. 1r has marginal flourishing that extends from the initial in the first line of text, down the inner margin and across the lower margin.
Plain initials in the 'Arabesque' style in red, green, and blue with occasional stylised acanthus leaf or 'petal' flourshing at the major and minor divisions of the texts.
Headings to the major and minor divisions of the texts usually written in red.

note.p:
Shelfmark and ownership inscription for St Augustine's Canterbury on f. ii recto: 'Di XII gra III
Liber Sancti Augustini Cant'.

Ownership inscription in ink on f. ii recto: 'Liber Joannis Twini senioris', i.e., John Twyne (?1505-1581) Twyne, John, approximately 1501-1581 , Canterbury schoolmaster and collector of manuscripts. G. H. Martin, ODNB:Twyne, John A. G. Watson, ‘John Twyne of Canterbury (d. 1581) as a Collector of Medieval Manuscripts: A Preliminary Investigation’, The Library, 6th ser., 8 (1986), pp. 133–151, esp. p. 148 [doi.org/10.1093/library/s6-VIII.2.133]
Trinity College bookplate of the College escutcheon with mantling and the motto 'Collegium S. Sci Indiuiduae Trinitatis in Academia Cantabrigiensi'on f. ii verso.
Title to the volume in ink in an early modern hand on f. iii recto, 'Elucidatio Artis Chirurgicae'.
Quires are numbered in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire; added by a 19th-century hand.

origin.origPlace: Either St Augustine's Abbey or Christ Church Cathedral Priory in Canterbury.
origin.note: Date and place of production assigned based on palaeographical and decorative features.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.31, ff. 245-248>

msItem.title: Index organised alphabetically by plant name
msItem.note: Index in a ?14th or ?15th century hand arranged alphabetically by plant name and supplied with Hindu-Arabic folio numbers written in the typical late-medieval forms; the hand that is responsible for the folio numbering in this index also appears to be the hand that added the medieval foliation to the centre of the upper margin of each recto through ff. 1-244.

msItem.title: Poem
msItem.note:
Full transcription: 'Mater cunctorum salua cetum monachorum
Spes infirmorum miserans miserere tuorum'.

This poem is also in Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 312, f. ii verso where it has an annotation in pencil in the same hand 'quod Bachon'. Bachon appears to have been a member of the community at St Augustine's Abbey in or after the 13th century, and his name also appears (?in a different hand) in Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 50, f. x recto .

msItem.title: Note on medieval weights and measures
msItem.note: Written in a ?14th century hand

msItem.title: Note about Ancient History
msItem.note: The note mentions Cham as the second son of Noah, and also mentions King Zarathustra (as 'Soroastes'
Written in a ?16th century hand.

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: In fair condition. The majority of the text on f. 245r has been washed or rubbed away. The lower portion of f. 246 has been repaired with conservation gauze at an unknown time to stabilise a large tear in the leaf. Folio 248 has been repaired (probably in the medieval period) with a patch made of a fragment of a medieval text leaf of perhaps the late-12th or early-13th century.

p.seg: Folios 247r are arranged in an informal and unruled two-column layout, and are written typically 32 lines to the column. The text on f. 247v is informally written in single-column format.

handNote.p: The text on ff. 245r-247r is written in an informal anglicana.

The note 'Mater cunctorum salua cetum monachorum
Spes infirmorum miserans miserere tuorum' on f. 247v is written in a textualis libraria.
The note about Ancient History on f. 247v is written in anglicana with secretary features.

decoNote.p: No significant decoration in this Part.

additions.note: Folio 248r-248v has a large defect in the original parchment leaf that has been repaired (probably in the medieval period) with a patch made from another medieval parchment text leaf. The repair-patch only has text visible on the portion of the patch visible on f. 248v and seems to contain fragments of chants for the divine office, e.g., 'Antra deserti teneris sub annis, civium turmis' written in a late 12th or early 13th century hand.

binding.p: The leaves in this Part (ff. 245-248, and in particular f. 248) bear traces of their use in a former binding. There are traces of adhesive residue on f. 248v in a pattern which suggests that it was once used as a pastedown in a former binding. In addition, damage to the centre of f. 248 is consistent with the presence of a strap-and-pin fastening on a former binding, with the pin-plate being mounted in the centre of the right board, as was typical for medieval English bindings.

origin.origDate: late 12th/13th century, with additions from early 14th to 16th centuries.
origin.p: It is not clear when these leaves (ff. 245-248) were added to the volume, but they bear marks of use from the early 14th century through to the 16th century, indicating that they were almost certainly written on while the volume was owned by St Augustine's Abbey in Canterbury, England. The patch repair to f. 248 has text in what appears to be in a late 12th or early 13th century hand, and so the repair must (obviously) post-date the creation of that textleaf.
origin.note: Place and date of production assigned based on palaeographic features, and supporting evidence derived from knowledge of the provenance of the rest of the volume.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.31, f. [f]

msItem.title: List of names and fragment of a legal document
msItem.note: This stub contains a fragmentary list of latinised English names in a ?14th century hand. Below the list of names is a fragment of a legal document that contains the name 'Johannem Sutlor'.

support.material: Parchment; former binding fragment pasted across the right hinge and probably once covered with a pastedown.

collation.p: Former binding fragment, now free stub (f. [f]) |

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part
No quire signatures particular to this Part

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part

supportDesc.condition: In good condition, although as it was once used to strengthen the binding rather than as a text-leaf within the context of this volume, some of the text on f. [f] recto emerges from the gutter.

p.seg: Informally written list of names and legal document; original mise-en-page no longer possible to determine due to the trimming of the leaf to re-use as a binding support.

handNote.p: Written in an informal script with anglicana features.

decoNote.p: No significant decoration in this Part.

binding.p: It seems very probable that this fragment (f. [f]) was once used as a binding support and was pasted from inside the back and over the hinge onto the inside of the right board before being covered with a pastedown as there are patterns of adhesive residue indicative of such use. Folio [f] (and the similar f. [a] at the beginning of the volume) were not noticed or described by M. R. James in his Catalogue of the Trinity College manuscripts printed between 1900-1904, so it seems likely that the pastedowns were lifted and the stubs were freed after 1904.

note.p: Date and place of production assigned based on palaeographical features and the forms of the names on this fragment.

change.persName: Dr Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer for the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries Project, Cambridge University Library
